WRITING.TEXT: Haha thanks I actually used it as an experiment piece to learn a new technique and I know I should have paid more attention to the details. I don't consider it a 100% finished piece so I know there are probably more things to fix then what you mentioned. The curve is not actually a road it was sort of a cliff/hill so. Thanks for checking it out anyway. Next time I paint farmland I'll keep your comment in mind.

www.noodos.jimdo.com/art-work
here is the rest of my work(most of it)

This country embraces thought-provoking work, anything that can make you feel a new way or something you have never seen or thought of. They are more... modernistic, imagine weird combinations of sculpture and painting... and definitely the digital side of things are picking up.
I am a major in Communication Arts, and most of classmates do a lot of digital work, 3-d, kinetic imaging, graphic design. I must be the only painter. Classical, traditional methods are still there but barely.
It is very much about the message and not so much about traditional skill alone. There are some galleries that show amazing skill, but some just show a bunch of shit thrown together claiming a solid reason for it. I have a couple friends making a living off painting, you just have to find the right people, the rich old people.
here, this will give you an example: http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?criteria=O%3ADE%3AI%3A5|G%3AHI%3AE%3A1 page_number=1 template_id=6 sort_order=2
I plan on staying away from the weird and just mastering painting

Thank you. It was a learning piece, I spent two months trying to experiment. I used a technique called scumbling, it's basically laying down color using a thin medium and moving it around with a dry brush to layer it over existing colors, which creates depth. You can see in the clothes, purples, and blues, reds, I layed them over eachother after letting them dry. The painting it in oils but since I used liquin, it dries within a day.
I am willing to sell but I am in the U.S right now and this painting is 32" x 40" It costs around a couple hundred($500-$1000) for shipping alone which means I would have to sell it fairly expensive.
I could probably look into making prints for you guys though
and here is the rest of my work www.noodos.jimdo.com/art-work
Thanks

Thanks! I will be sharing more soon and here is more of my paintings
www.noodos.jimdo.com/art-work

Hi and thank you. So last summer I visited my relatives in India and I took many pictures. This was on my uncles farm and it is one of the workers. I attend VCU here in the U.S and it is pretty great, ranked #1 public art school. I showed the pictures to my professor and he had a lot to say about the picture for this, said he felt a lot of energy from it so I decided to paint it. I was trying new techniques in this painting called scumbling and using fast drying medium call liquin. I started by building a wooden panel and just primed it, no canvas involved. I draw it out in pencil first and started covering big sections in different colors. I just slowly go from big areas to details. When the details came I used scumbling, which is putting down paint, very small amount and pushing it around, with thin fast drying medium, it dries over the other colors instead of taking their place. You can see in the clothing how there are a lot of colors, purples reds etc. I just went in with each other and placed each other down with one brush and using a dry brush, moved the paint around. It' s a really cool effect. Sorry for the long explanation.

Here you go, it's the first painting
http://noodos.jimdo.com/art-work
I have a few paintings I did in India and will post them over time. Thanks so much
http://noodos.jimdo.com/art-work/ Thanks and Enjoy
Thank you! It's my life

WRITING.TEXT:
I'm setting up prints at the moment, I will get back to you. Thank you :)
Here is my work if you need to see more
http://rdeepmedia.wordpress.com/the-work-of-raman-singh/

Yes I am using a bamboo tablet in photoshop. It's not the same without that because a mouse cannot be pressure sensitive. The pen and pad is amazing because it can pick up pressure so well and with the right settings in PhotoShop you can draw and paint like you would traditionally.

Hard to say an exact price. I have rarely had to mail them to someone but I do commissions around my area anywhere from 100-1000$ it depends on the size and content. Most portraits I've sold were around $300-$500. Murals go for more, I'm working on one for $1600. I am thinking of a way I can start selling prints, this is actually my first time working digitally so I am figuring things out printing wise and would love to sell this as a print , esp on this subreddit. Maybe even give out some free ones.

That's flattering and it happens to me all the time. But you can't compare someone's highlight reels to your behind the scenes. You must look up, get up and don't ever quit. Aim higher , try to out do whatever it is you think is impossible. Nothing is impossible. You got this.

Please, I built my knowledge of color and light from oil painting. Here are some of my oil paintings, http://rdeepmedia.wordpress.com/the-work-of-raman-singh/
Just because I am using digital doesn't mean that it is cheating. You still have to know how to PAINT. The process is very similar to oil painting
:) thank you
I painted it digitally in PhotoShop using a tablet so that's why I was able to layer the colors so smoothly :)

WRITING.TITLE: Hey guys, just wanted to share something I just finished painting

IDAP of Buddha

WRITING.TEXT: Honestly, I love India and I love my family and friends there. I come visit from the U.S every summer and over the years, I've noticed India slipping. I find it less and less comfortable each year and last year I told myself I wouldn't come back because of my terrible experience. I always visit Punjab and my family there. Over the years I've noticed my cousins, uncles and friends just kind of lose their selves to drugs and alcohol. I've also noticed kids selling drugs more and more on the streets and everyone basically losing touch of reality. It may just be a Punjab thing but it feels like there is really nothing else for them to do. They feel they are at a dead-end in life. I know I am in no position to judge them but really what else is there ? What is life for people like that? I mean how can they improve instead of just getting by . Another thing , the corruption, I feel disgusted everytime I have to fight off the stupid guards trying to steal my money at the exit of the Delhi airport, Wtf, its a serious problem. Every time they try to haggle the shit out of me. There are many similar instances when I come to India and that is one of the reasons I can appreciate the u.s, people here don't get away with shit like that. Sorry if this was irrelevant but I do love India, I am an art major and paint India all the time.

In 5th grade I read " A Taste of Blackberries". Saddest thing ever. I will still tear up thinking about it. It's about a little boy who's best friend is allergic to bee stings. They are playing one summer and his friend gets stung by a couple bees and he dies. The main boy is in disbelief and sometimes even goes to his friends house after school like he used, only to find his mother.

It's the truth man, hawks game was so painful to watch. He was stubborn and selfish for staying in, cousins would have done much better if they had given him a chance. Griffen said it at the end of the game, "I felt I was the best man on our team to get the job done so I stayed out there " (somethin like that).

WRITING.TEXT: Now that I think about it, its insane. So back in the kazaa days, I was in 5th grade tryin to download dragonballz episodes and accidently downloaded an amv with "a place for my head". My life was never the same. I barely knew English an had never listened to music before but to this day LP has always been there.
